title: St Martin's Church, Allerton Mauleverer
text:
St Martin's Church is a historic <a href="Anglican">Anglican</a> church in the village of <a href="Allerton%20Mauleverer">Allerton Mauleverer</a>, <a href="North%20Yorkshire">North Yorkshire</a>, England. It is recorded in the <a href="National%20Heritage%20List%20for%20England">National Heritage List for England</a> as a designated Grade II* <a href="Listed%20building%23England%20and%20Wales">listed building</a>, and is under the care of The <a href="Churches%20Conservation%20Trust">Churches Conservation Trust</a>. It is sited just outside Allerton Park, the grounds of <a href="Allerton%20Castle">Allerton Castle</a>, which has been the home of the <a href="Mauleverer%20Baronets">Mauleverer</a> family for nearly 700 years.
History.
A church <a href="dedication">dedicated</a> to Saint Martin was first built on the site by a member of the Mauleverer family in the late 12th or early 13th century. The present church was remodelled in 1745–46 for <a href="Richard%20Arundell%20%28died%201758%29">Richard Arundell</a>, heir to the Mauleverers and MP for <a href="Knaresborough%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Knaresborough</a>. St Martin's was declared redundant on 1 December 1971, and was <a href="vesting">vested</a> in the Trust on 27 July 1973.
Architecture.
Exterior.
St Martin's is constructed in <a href="ashlar">ashlar</a> on its west front, and in <a href="course%20%28architecture%29">coursed</a> <a href="limestone">limestone</a> elsewhere. It is roofed in stone slates, and the architectural style is <a href="Romanesque%20Revival%20architecture">Norman revival</a>. Its plan consists of a six-<a href="bay%20%28architecture%29">bay</a> <a href="nave">nave</a> with north and south <a href="aisle">aisle</a>s and <a href="transept">transept</a>s, and a two-bay <a href="chancel">chancel</a>. Between the nave and chancel is a central tower. At the west front are three <a href="gable">gable</a>s at the ends of the nave and the aisles. The nave has a central round-headed doorway, over which is a circular window. On each side of this window is a round-headed window. The west fronts of the aisles protrude slightly forward from the nave, and each contains a round-headed window between two <a href="pilaster">pilaster</a>s. Along the sides of the church are four round-headed windows, and the windows in the transepts have two lights. The east window has five lights and is in <a href="English%20Gothic%20architecture%23Perpendicular%20Gothic">Perpendicular</a> style. The tower has three stages; in the top stage are two round-headed bell openings on each side. On the tower is a pyramidal roof with a <a href="weather%20vane">weather vane</a>.
Interior.
Inside the church is a vase-shaped <a href="baptismal%20font">font</a>, a two-decker <a href="pulpit">pulpit</a> with a <a href="sounding%20board">sounding board</a>, and <a href="panelling">panelled</a> <a href="box%20pew">box pew</a>s. Between the nave and the chancel, and between the nave and the transepts, are iron gates. The church has a <a href="hammerbeam%20roof">hammerbeam roof</a> and on the chancel arch is a painting of <a href="Moses">Moses</a> and <a href="Aaron">Aaron</a>. In the north transepts are four <a href="effigy">effigies</a>; two of these are in wood depicting <a href="knight">knight</a>s with crossed legs dating from the late 13th or the early 14th century; the other two are in <a href="alabaster">alabaster</a>, dated 1475, and represent Sir John Mauleverer and his wife. In the south transept is the large tomb of Mrs Mary Thornton who died in 1800.
